ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
TRAFFIC LIGHT BREAKDOWNS


    1. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for National Development what are the reasons for breakdowns of traffic lights and what measures are being taken to improve the situation.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Sir, about 20% of traffic light breakdowns are caused by external factors such as power failure, traffic accidents and cable damage. The other 80% are caused by malfunction of the traffic light equipment. Such equipment are subject to heat, rain, dust and vibration and are in continuous operation round the clock.

    Out of a total of 960 traffic lights, the average breakdown is only three traffic lights per day. This works out to 99.7% reliability. Although we will try to improve on this level of reliability, we must recognize that we are close to a limit that is technically feasible and cost-effective.

    The other approach is to ensure a quicker response to breakdowns of traffic lights. Besides its in-house resources, the Public Works Department also maintains a hotline for the public to call should they come across any traffic light not working properly. This has enabled the PWD to attend to all such cases promptly.

    The PWD intends to bring all traffic lights under central computer control, so that any malfunction of traffic lights can be detected much earlier and rectified within a shorter time.

    Resumption of Debate on Question [29th March, 1988],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head P of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Dr Aline K. Wong].

    Question again proposed.

     The Acting Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, first, I would like to thank the Members for Fengshan and Changkat for their support of the community hospital concept and also for the cautionary notes from the Member for Fengshan.

    Sir, the community hospital concept developed from the recognition that acute hospitals are expensive to build and even more expensive to operate. Case studies of patients in acute hospitals revealed that 10-15% of them need not be occupying such expensive beds. Many of these patients are in the convalescent phase of their illness. Examples will be orthopaedic and other patients recovering from major surgery, and stroke patients requiring active rehabilitation. These patients will make up a major portion of the community hospital's patient load.

    The community hospital will also provide respite care to the elderly sick patients so as to relieve the strain on the care givers. However, the hospital is not meant to be a chronic sick hospital nor is it meant primarily for the elderly sick. It will provide rehabilitative services and basic laboratory and X-ray services. It will have a small complement of doctors and will receive support from a nearby acute hospital. However, it will not be offering accident and emergency services.

    As the Member for Changkat has pointed out, we are considering leasing out clinic space to the general practitioners. But these GPs will only be responsible for their own patients who need to be hospitalized.

    The Member for Changkat also asked why is the community hospital is to be located in Ang Mo Kio and not Toa Payoh or Queenstown. In the planning of a new hospital, we have to take into consideration the availability of hospitals in the vicinity. Both Toa Payoh and Queenstown are already adequately served. With the intensive housing development in the

Column: 1687

north-eastern part of the island, the new community hospital in Ang Mo Kio will conveniently serve residents in Ang Mo Kio, Yishun, Bishan, Hougang and, of course, Toa Payoh.

    The Member also asked whether the hospital, since it will be having community participation at the board level, will be autonomously managed. The answer is yes. It will also have subsidized wards. My Ministry will be giving the hospital a subvention to provide subsidized services. The details have yet to be worked out and I will keep the Member for Changkat's views in mind.

    Sir, I also want to thank the Member for Fengshan for his concern as to whether such a hospital will be cost effective. That was also my concern when the details were first presented to me. If the community hospital is designed as a mini acute hospital with full-fledged medical departments and equipped with a whole spectrum of investigative equipment along with the whole team of para-medical personnel, then I can assure this House that it will be a disaster, cost-wise. However, by keeping the hospital as a low-activity institution, overheads can then be kept to a minimum level. With 200 beds, the hospital will be able to justify its own management and administrative personnel and it will also be able to link up with our existing hospitals, tap their expertise and utilize the various operating systems thereby minimizing the costs.

    Sir, of course, the ideal solution will be to build the hospital as a wing of Toa Payoh Hospital. Unfortunately, Toa Payoh Hospital suffers from a severe lack of space. It will not be able to accommodate an additional 200-bedded wing. On the other hand, SGH and Tan Tock Seng Hospital are already far too large. Members may be interested to know that in many countries, hospitals as large as SGH and Tan Tock Seng Hospital are, in fact, the exceptions rather than the rule. In fact, hospital planners believe that a 200-bedded to 400-bedded hospital is probably more cost effective because they are easier to manage.

Column: 1688



    My Ministry also shares the concern of the Member for Fengshan that it may be regarded as a second class hospital. We will be reviewing what must be done to prevent this image from developing. As with any new concept, education of the general public is very important. Likewise, with the staff and the medical fraternity that will be using it.

    Sir, this concept of a low-activity community hospital is not new. It has been introduced in many countries and it has worked. We are confident that given the proper preparations, this concept will work in Singapore too.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching (Kaki Bukit): Sir, our total health expenditure as a nation is about 3% of our GDP today. This ratio is indeed low when we compare with the 8-12% ratio experienced in most developed countries. But as our population ages and as we become wealthier, our demand for health care will inevitably increase. Our health expenditure as a proportion of our GDP will increase.

    Sir, my concern is: as demand for health care continues to increase, where do we strike a balance between the supply and demand for health care without unnecessarily pushing up the price of health care services? We could continue to increase the supply in Government hospitals through additional and better facilities and this means heavier health expenditure on the part of the Government. Private hospitals could increase their hospital resources to meet greater demand and this means heavier investment expenditure.

    Sir, we cannot continue to increase supply indefintely. I think the supply of health care is finite. There is a limit to which supply resources can grow. At some stage, these increases will have to be passed on to consumers in the form of higher prices. Then there is a danger that the price of health care may be pushed up to a level which will go beyond the reach of the man in the street.

    The solution to this fear lies in our keeping demand for health care as low as possible. One way to achieve this is through continuous health education and preventive health care. Currently, the

Column: 1689

Ministry of Health spends about $20-$30 million a year on these activities. This amount is small. It is peanuts compared with the total Ministry's budget of $500 million. I think greater emphasis should be placed in these areas and more should be spent on these activities. May I ask the Minister what is his Ministry doing to try to reduce the demand for health care in the long run? Is there a role for the private sector here? And how can the private medical sector play that role? Is it not in the interest of the private medical sector not to try to reduce demand for health care, bearing in mind that that sector has its own economic interests?

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Sir, it is a fact that the demand for health care of our ageing population is growing year after year. In 1987, the aged, 60 years and above, numbered 212,000, 9,000 semi-ambulant and 1,300 bedridden. By the year 2000, the aged is projected to reach 300,000. What impact has this on our health service? Has the Ministry a long-term strategy to meet this changing needs on our health service? What about its impact on our present health plans? Should there be a revision of the present health plans?

    As an example, I understand that the Kandang Kerbau Hospital is due to be extensively upgraded or even replaced by a new maternity hospital. The question is: is there a need for such a large maternity hospital in the future, bearing in mind the declining birth rate problem? Who will demand our health services more in the future? The newborn or the elderly?

    Sir, the basic objective of health care to the elderly is to prevent a decline in the quality of life in old age caused by the development of degenerative diseases. Or to quote the experts, "to add life to years and not years to life". Towards this objective, the Government is encouraging the elderly, including the sick, to stay at home to be looked after by their families. This is right. For who can give better care, love, respect and dignity to a sick elderly other than his or her own family. However, to look after a sick elderly in the home is not an easy task. And I hope the Minister is aware of the many problems faced by

Column: 1690

these families. I want to encourage the Minister to look into more ways and means to help these families. I think up to now, the help given is rather limited. But I am not asking for a welfare scheme. I am asking the Minister to find all ways and means to help these families to help them to look after the sick at home so that they will not be forced to have to go to hospital or to go to nursing homes.

    Sir, there is no comprehensive programme aimed at helping all these families who have aged sick at home. Yet the Government is encouraging families to keep their aged sick at home. For example, the Home Nursing Foundation is supposed to be a national organization to help give assistance and advice to some 10,000 disabled and sick elderly. But how big is this organization? Can it really look after all these elderly sick and give help to the families? I am surprised to learn, for example, that the Ministry is only providing 42 nurses for the Foundation. As far as I know, no medical staff has been seconded to the Foundation. Can the Minister tell me how many of the total number of elderly sick in Singapore are actually receiving help from the Foundation? The Foundation has set up two senior citizens' health centres and plans to build three more in the next four years. My question is whether the number and the size of these centres are adequate to cope with the increasing number of elderly sick? For example, how many elderly sick can be accommodated in the day care centre and the rehabilitation facilities that it has within these centres? What I want to know is, is the Ministry pursuing a policy of helping only those who seek help from them or, a more enlightened one, to help all those who need help?

    I have heard of a number of problems faced by these families. One is transport. It is very difficult to transport a disabled elderly from the home to the outpatient clinics, the polyclinics, and even to the day care centre. The ordinary vehicles are not suitable for this purpose and taxi drivers are quite reluctant to accept the disabled elderly. I want to know whether the Minister would consider perhaps providing the ambulance service for this purpose.

Column: 1691



    The other point I want to make is that the problems faced by the sick elderly are not only health problems. In fact, they are mainly social problems. The social problems are looked after by the Ministry of Community Development which recently has introduced a number of home-help schemes. The point is, as the health and social service are inter-related, should there not be a coordinating committee between the two Ministries to ensure a more efficient service to the elderly and to avoid any miscommunication between the two Ministries. As an illustration, the Ministry of Community Development provides a meal delivery service to the homes. This to them seems a very good idea. But from the health point of view, it may not be so. This is because keeping the disabled elderly physically inactive and serving them without regard to their actual physical capabilities will actually make their disability worse. So instead of delivering cooked meals to these people, maybe the Ministry should arrange for the neighbours or volunteers to do the marketing for these disabled people and encourage them to do the cooking and other light household chores. This will increase their mobility and help them to cope better with their physical disability. In this respect, keeping the disabled mobile at home is such an important thing. Would the Minister consider giving some assistance to set up simple physiotherapy devices in the home, such as those bars and pulleys to ensure that the disabled elderly are kept active on a daily basis.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: The Member for Kaki Bukit has asked about health education. Sir, I would like to seek the Member's concurrence for me to give him the reply later, as another Member has also raised a cut on the same item.

    Sir, the Member for Telok Blangah asked whether my Ministry takes into consideration the long-term demographic changes to our population when planning our health services for today and the future. Sir, the answer is a definite yes. Long-term planning must take into consideration the relevant changes that are happening to our population. We are very careful because health services are expensive,

Column: 1692

especially new institutions. This way, money is not spent unnecessarily. The same applies to the redevelopment of Kandang Kerbau Hospital. Sir, although the crude birth rate is declining, the Member would be happy to know that in terms of actual babies the number need not necessarily be decreasing. In fact, our projection is that because of the large cohort of women that were born during the 1950's and 1960's, in the next 10 years the number of births will peak at about 50,000 a year versus today's 40,000 to 43,000 a year. After that, we expect the number of babies born to stabilize at about 45,000, a number which is again slightly higher than today's figure. So I would like to assure the Member for Telok Blangah that the redevelopment of Kandang Kerbau Hospital is very much warranted.

    Sir, in terms of the elderly sick, the Ministry is looking into the various ways and means of helping the elderly sick at home. He asked whether we are only helping those who approached us or are we helping all who needed the help? We would like to help all who need to be helped. But how do we know that they need to be helped. We must get the feedback somehow. And we do get referrals to our Home Nursing Foundation, which is the key organization providing home care for the aged. These referrals are from our hospitals, the outpatient clinics, the private sector doctors and, of course, the Ministry of Community Development. So we do get as much feedback as we can. Also to keep Singaporeans aware of the availability of such a service, last year, we sent out together with the PUB bills, pamphlets on the Home Nursing Foundation to a total of 760,000 households. So we do try to publicize the availability of home nursing by the Foundation.

    With regard to the number of patients who are being cared for, last year a total of 3,311 patients were home-nursed and the Home Nursing Foundation provided a total of 33,663 home nursing cases. None who approached us were rejected. So the manpower is adequate to cater for their needs. Of course, in line with the ageing population over the next 5, 10, 15 years, should the demand increase, we must make sure that we help the Home Nursing

Column: 1693

Foundation to adequately staff its nursing ranks.

    Sir, he asked about transportation for the elderly sick who need to go to the senior citizens' health care centres. The Home Nursing Foundation does have ambulances available and, when requested, they will fetch these patients to the senior citizens' health care centres for their rehabilitation, for the day care.

    We are also coordinating very closely with the Ministry of Community Development in terms of provision of services to the elderly sick. In fact, my Ministry is also represented on the MCD's Committee for the Aged and there is a lot of cross-sharing of information and data between the two Ministries.

    Sir, he asked about the meal delivery service being provided for by MCD. I am not too sure whether what he says is correct because the meal delivery is only provided for those who are so sick that they are unable to help themselves in terms of cooking their food requirements. If they are too sick to cook, it is going to be very difficult to force them to cook their own meals. That is why the meal service has been made available. Of course, the emphasis must be to teach our elderly to keep themselves fit, to keep themselves mobile, active and to be able to exercise. So we do try to encourage them not to be confined to the bed and that they should come out to exercise, stretch their legs a little bit, because it is necessary.

    As to the installation of simple rehabilitative devices at home, I will ask my officials to look into it.

     Dr Koh Lam Son: Sir, can I seek a point of clarification, a very quick one. I think the Minister is wrong to say that the meals delivery is only provided to those people who are very sick. I think it is provided to any disabled who cannot go out of their home or have help from the family or neighbours to go and buy their meals. So it is not for people who are so sick that they cannot cook.

    The other disagreement I have with the Acting Minister, I am sorry to say that, is that he does not have to wait for referrals to reach out to these families who have

Column: 1694

sick aged. There is other feedback that you can look into. If there is a will to help, you will find a way. I am happy to give him the figures in Telok Blangah if he wants.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the channels are always open. It is up to those organizations who are aware of such patients to make use of the channels. It is not possible for us to go round, checking every household to see whether there are elderly sick. The emphasis must be to make sure that the availability of the services is publicized so that families with elderly sick who require help, who require home nursing, can easily pick up the phone and call up the HNF. W must also ensure that the community organizations are also aware that HNF does exist and when they come across people living in their vicinity who require help, they can also help these people by calling up the HNF. So the key is to make sure that channels are open, the service is widely known and that HNF will be able to react and help them.

    With regard to the meal delivery, I do not want to belabour the point but I think the MCD does vet the request carefully to ensure that the requests are justified.

     The Chairman: Dr Ang Kok Peng is not here. Dr Aline Wong.

     Dr Aline K. Wong (Changkat): We would like to thank the Minister for his replies. Maybe I would like to take just one or two seconds to make a few comments on his response on the catastrophic illness insurance scheme. Sir, the Acting Minister told the House that his Ministry has actually started to look at this matter about two years back and he is going to send some people from his Ministry to the United States to make a thorough study of how health insurance schemes work in the United States, partly to avoid the kind of pitfalls the schemes have fallen into and partly to learn from their experience. I would like to remind the Acting Minister that apart from seeking overseas' opinion, seeking to learn from the experience of the United States, there are also some people here in Singapore who have that kind of knowledge and capacity to be able to offer some advice, apart from those who sit on the Health Advisory Council. These include the academics at the NUS as well as other

Column: 1695

medical professionals who have been trained overseas and have come back with first-hand knowledge of the problem.

    While his team is making a study on the health insurance system of the United States, may I also ask him to bear in mind to study the health maintenance organization scheme which seems to be gaining increasing acceptance in the United States among the private sector. It seems to be a rather effective way of keeping down health costs and keeping down health costs is a very important concern in the minds of my GPC members, as the Member for Kaki Bukit also just pointed out.

    With that, may I thank the Minister and I beg to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

     Dr Ho Tat Kin (Boon Teck): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head P be reduced by $10 in respect of Code PA 1000 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, admission to Government hospitals and visits to Government outpatient clinics have risen steadily in the last 10 years. Between 1971 and 1980, the annual rate of admission to hospitals increased from 76 per thousand population to 110 per thousand. The rate of increase over the decade averaged 4.3% per annum. This will continue to increase as the population grows and age, becomes more affluent and health conscious. In fact, the Ministry of Health projected that by the year 2000 the admission to hospitals will increase to 135 per thousand population. Sir, here I share the same concern as the Member for Kaki Bukit on the increasing medical expenses needed.

    People are generally more interested in having good health and, when that fails, good health care. Promotion of better health will in the long run help to reduce the rate of hospital admissions. Good preventive medicine and health education are important for good health and the key to good health is to educate the people to change their bad lifestyles such as excessive smoking, excessive alcohol consump-

Column: 1696

tion and excessive food and undue stress. The Ministry of Health's Training and Health Education Service has been doing a good job in the past and I feel they can do more.

    Most of us only consult a doctor when we have some disturbing symptoms or feel physically or mentally below par. We seldom go for health checks or screening. It was found that in the United States of America, one out of 10 men is in need of treatment for high blood pressure and four women in every 1,000 have been found to have breast cancer where a quarter of these could have been detected by X-rays. Health screenings, therefore, help to give early warning of our health conditions. I would like to suggest to the Minister to promote health screening for the people either on an annual basis or bi-annual basis. Health screening should not be just tests taken for blood, blood pressure, ECG and chest X-rays. It should include the opportunity for the person and the doctor to discuss any medical, pyschological and other problems with a view to helping the person to improve his health by changing to a better and healthier life-style. And to encourage people to go for health screening, I would like to urge the Ministry to allow the Medisave scheme to be used. But to prevent abuse, the Ministry should set a ceiling equivalent to that charged at Government hospitals for similar screenings.

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong (Cairnhill): Sir, the 1985 report of the Economic Committee has emphasized the need for Singapore to be developed as an international medical centre of excellence. May I ask the Acting Minister for a progress report on what his Ministry has done to help Singapore achieve this objective. More specifically, I hope the Acting Minister can enlighten this House on the manpower development plans, especially in the training of doctors, nurses, medical specialists, technologists and technicians.

    I understand that there are currently only about 2,600 doctors in Singapore, giving a doctor to population ratio of about 1:1000. Can the Acting Minister confirm if there are sufficient doctors in Singapore to serve 2.6 million Singaporeans as well as the additional potential market of

Column: 1697

thousands of Indonesians, Malaysians, Thais and Filipinos who may come to Singapore for their medical treatment. Can the Acting Minister inform this House the projected doctor to population ratio that his Ministry is targetting for, and are we producing enough medical graduates to meet our goal of establishing Singapore as a Centre of Medical Excellence?

    There is a tremendous demand from Singapore students to study medicine, but the National University of Singapore seems to limit the intake of new students into the Medical Faculty to about 200 a year. Can the Acting Minister inform this House the additional doctors required over the next 10 years so that NUS can expand its Medical Faculty accordingly?

    Another serious complaint that I have often heard from overseas visitors is the high cost of our medical treatment, especially in the private hospitals. May I therefore ask the Acting Minister if his Ministry has been able to monitor the medical fees charged by our specialists so that they will not overcharge their patients and give Singapore a bad image. Can the Acting Minister also inform this House the kind of incentives, for example, accelerated depreciation allowance and pioneer service status for investments in specialized medical facilities and services to help the medical profession to be more cost competitive?

     Dr S. Vasoo (Bo Wen): Sir, I shall be brief otherwise I know you will conduct a verbal surgery. The health services are at the moment undergoing restructuring. I am all for restructuring provided that at the end of the day, after restructuring, the health services will remain within the reach of many. If at the end of the day, after the health services have been restructured, it does not come within the reach of the ordinary people, then I say we have failed in our restructuring effort and exercises.

    I have a few pertinent questions in my mind. Firstly, is the restructuring going to improve the efficiency and the effectiveness of the health services? Secondly, is the restructuring going to incur a steep increase in terms of medical fees? Thirdly, as a result of this restructuring, would there be more emphasis on preventive and

Column: 1698

community health programmes? These are some of the pertinent concerns raised by many ordinary citizens who are and will be using the health services. I gather that in their mind, restructuring connotes basically an increase in fee structure at the end of the day and I feel that the Ministry has to take much effort to reassure them that restructuring means that there will be more efficient and effective services.

    The average citizen has no difficulty in using our health services when these are required. However, the situation is changing because the cost of health care is increasing. The hospital charges have so far increased steadily over the years and I hope that the hospital charges will remain within reach for the ordinary citizens who would become consumers of health services. It is hoped that the restructuring of the hospital will not push up hospital charges so steeply that those who really need health care would find it inaccessible.

    Sir, it is good in trying to have good buildings, sterile environment, but it will be no good if such buildings and services become not accessible to the ordinary people who need health care and attention. I hope that our health services will not run into that situation.

    The nagging concern among many people is that C class beds will be phased out and it will be eventually replaced by B2. Sir, one must not forget that the frontiers of medicine have no barriers. I urge that we do not create much financial burden so that health care becomes less affordable to those who need it.

    In conclusion, I have two pertinent questions for the Minister. Would the restructuring phase out the C class beds completely? Would charges of C class and B2 class beds be increased this year?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, I will take the points from the Members for Kaki Bukit and Boon Teck together. Both Members have expressed their concerns on the prospects of increasing demand for health care, especially as Singaporeans become even more affluent in the future. They have asked that the Ministry focuses more on preventive health care and health education.

Within Singapore everyone - no matter whatever position he holds - knows that if he is corrupt, the law will deal with him firmly. We have been able to do this because of, first, the Government's consistent and firm position against corruption. Secondly, because of our laws, especially the Prevention of Corruption Act, and thirdly, because the laws are implemented fearlessly and effectively by a CPIB that is thorough and impartial in its work. Members would recall that the Commission of Inquiry into the late Mr Teh Cheang Wan stated, and I quote:

    'Singapore has an enviable reputation for the honesty and integrity of its public institutions. This reputation is a hard-earned national asset which should be protected and preserved.'

    But how do we protect and preserve it? We can say of the prevention of corruption as Jefferson said of liberty - "eternal vigilance is the price of liberty". Methods of corruption are always undercover and very difficult to detect. Corruption is cunning in hiding its tracks over a long period of time. Therefore, we must be prepared to adopt any new legal procedures which will serve as further deterrents against corruption.

    This Bill provides an effective new weapon in dealing with corruption. It strikes effectively at the unexplained assets of persons convicted of corruption offences. Under the Bill, the courts can make confiscation orders in respect of such unexplained assets and can restrain their disposal before the court proceedings are concluded against such persons. This will be in addition to other penalties

Column: 1718

which the court may impose under existing law.

    I think Members know that we already have the Prevention of Corruption Act. However, this existing law is not sufficiently adequate to deal with the confiscation and recovery of corruption benefits. Under the present law, a person convicted of a corruption offence is ordered to pay by way of penalty only a sum equal to the amount of the gratification which he has received or the value of that gratification. This payment of penalty, it may be noted, is confined to the value of the gratification received for the offence for which he was convicted or for other offences for which consideration was taken into account.

    But let us take the case of an offender who has been corrupt prior to that particular offence for which there was discovery and for which he was charged. He may have assets which are clearly disproportionate to his known sources of income and for which he can give no satisfactory explanation. Such assets, under existing law, cannot be confiscated unless it is proved that he has actualy derived those assets by corruption. But these are matters which are specially within his own knowledge and it would be difficult, if not, impossible to obtain evidence concerning them.

    The Bill, therefore, provides new powers for tracing and freezing the benefits of corruption and for confiscating those benefits.

    The principles in this Bill are not new. Britain and Australia are among the countries that have legislation for the confiscation of property and assets which were illegally obtained. The provisions of this Bill before the House are modelled on the United Kingdom's Drug Trafficking Offences Act of 1986 with modifications and adaptations for our purposes except for clauses 21 and 22 which are adapted from the Australian Proceeds of Crime Act, 1987. For the information of hon.     Under clause 4, Sir, where a person has been convicted of a corruption offence and the Public Prosecutor makes an application to the court, the court shall make a confiscation order against the defendant in respect of benefits derived by him from corruption. The safeguard is that the court must be satisfied that such benefits have been so derived. A person is deemed to have derived benefits from corruption if he holds or has held assets disproportionate to his known sources of income, the holding of which he cannot explain to the satisfaction of the court. The onus of explaining assets which are disproportionate to the defendant's known sources of income is placed on him. This is fair since it will only apply after he has been convicted of a corruption offence and that he is in the best position to explain how he derived those assets.

    Clause 5 provides for the assessment of the value of the benefits derived by the defendant from corruption. Clause 6 will enable the prosecution to tender a statement to the court as to any matters relevant to the determination of the benefits derived by the defendant from corruption. Such a statement, if accepted by the defendant, would provide a conclusive way of determining the amount of the confiscation order. The defendant can, however, still of course dispute this statement and he may tender his own statement.

    Sir, the Bil provides for the defendant to be liable to imprisonment where any confiscation order made by the court is not satisfied. The periods of imprisonment in default of payment of the confiscation order is in accordance with a progressive scale depending on the amount involved.

    To ensure that the assets derived from corruption are not disposed of by the defendant before the conclusion of the court proceedings, the High Court can make what is known as restraint orders. Such restraint orders, like an injunction, will prohibit any person from dealing with any realizable property of the offender. It may be made only on the application of the Public Prosecutor and the effect will be to freeze the property and assets which

    Sir, safeguards for the interests of innocent third parties are provided in the Bill.
